column4: I just ran 'lspci -v' and it came back telling me my sound card was "Creative Labs Unknown device 0005"... where else can I find what sound card I have?
Are you looking for the sound driver you want to use? If so, it's likely emu10k1.. Otherwise look at your hardware vendor, or look at the card itself
Oh... just remembered I have a Sound Blaster X-Fi... but http://www.alsa-project.org/alsa-doc/index.php?vendor=vendor-Creative_Labs#matrix says X-Fi doesn't have support yet.
Is there any way at all to get sound?
Well, keep an eye on the new releases of ALSA.. That's unfortunate.
Maybe OSS has support
OSS...? You lost me there.
Open Sound System
Where would I get to their database?
It's probably not as great as ALSA, but you'd get sound in most applications with OSS and ALSA emulation.
Sorry, no idea.. Google it. I'd hate to say it but you sound pretty boned
Yeah... this sucks.
I'll look around and see if I can find anything
It looks like ALSA is working on a driver for it
Yeah, Creative Labs just updated the architecture for it, so I think it may be a while.
If you really want to use Linux, do what I did; buy a cheap $30 Audigy 2.. Works great.
Meh, then I'd have to switch out every time I booted up with Vista.

Just leave the Audigy 2 in there, there's not a huge difference between the performance -- they both support hardware mixing, one has slightly better quality that is likely not to be even supported in most games
The only real performance decrease would be if you but a non-hardware mixing sound card, in which Window's audio would have to waste CPU cycles on using it's software mixer :)
Alright, I'll check it out.
Alright, just look on the ALSA database for supported Audigy 2 models
There are some Audigy 2's that don't have hardware mixing, which is lame.. so make sure it's a hardware mixing supported model :)
Sweet, props for the help man.
And the name of the driver for the X-Fi is CA20k1, when the driver named ca20k1 comes out you'll have support ;)
